009package imagingbook.core.resource;
010
011import java.io.File;
012import java.io.InputStream;
013import java.net.URL;
014
015/**
016 * <p>
017 * This interface is supposed to be implemented by some enum class that
018 * specifies the root of a resource tree. The following example defines
019 * such an enum type that refers to three images. The path relative 
020 * to the location of the enum class itself must be specified
021 * and images must be stored there.
022 * The enum type must define an appropriate constructor and implement
023 * method {@link #getFileName()}:
024 * </p>
025
026 * <pre>
027 * public enum MyImages implements NamedResource {
028 *      image1("image1.tif"),
029 *      image2("image2.png"),
030 *      image3("jpegs/image3.jpg");
031 * 
032 *      // field to associate the resource's file name
033 *      private final String filename;
034 * 
035 *      &#64;Override
036 *      public String getFileName() {
037 *              return filename;
038 *      }
039 * 
040 *      // constructor
041 *      MyImages(String filename) {
042 *              this.filename = filename;
043 *      }
044 * }</pre>
045 * <p>
046 * By default, resource files are assumed to be placed in a folder
047 * with the same name as the resource class (i.e., "MyImages") relative
048 * to the location of the class.
049 * Resources may then only be referenced by their enum-name, for example,
050 * </p>
051 * <pre>
052 * URI uri = MyImages.image1.getURI();
053 * ImagePlus im = IJ.openImage(uri.toString());
054 * </pre>
055 * <p>
056 * The benefit of using a named resource (over specifying resources by path strings) 
057 * is that the resource is guaranteed to exist at compile time (this is assured
058 * by validating the existence of all named resources in the test phase) and can be retrieved
059 * even if located inside a JAR file.
060 * </p>
061 * @see ImageResource
062 * @author WB
063 * @version 2022/08/23
064 */
065public interface NamedResource {
066        
067        /**
068         * Returns the resource directory relative to the implementing class.
069         * The default implementations assumes that this is a single-level directory
070         * with exactly the same name as the implementing class.
071         * Implementations may override this definition to return some other 
072         * relative directory.
073         * 
074         * @return the relative resource directory for the associated resource
075         */
076        public default String getRelativeDirectory() {
077                return this.getClass().getSimpleName();
078        }
079        
080        /**
081         * Returns the file name of the associated resource.
082         * 
083         * @return the name of the resource file
084         */
085        public String getFileName();
086        
087        /**
088         * Returns the path to the associated resource relative to the
089         * location of the implementing class.
090         * This method is not supposed to be overridden.
091         * 
092         * @return the relative path to the associated resource
093         */
094        public default String getRelativePath() {
095                return getRelativeDirectory() + "/" + getFileName();
096        }
097        
098        /**
099         * Returns the URL to the associated resource.
100         * This method is not supposed to be overridden.
101         * 
102         * @return the URL to the associated resource
103         */
104        public default URL getURL() {
105                Class<?> clazz = this.getClass();
106                return clazz.getResource(this.getRelativePath());
107        }
108        
109//      @Deprecated
110//      public default URI getURI() {
111//              try {
112//                      return getURL().toURI();
113//              } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
114//                      return null;
115//              }
116//      }
117        
118//      /**
119//       * Returns the {@link Path} to the associated resource object.
120//       * @return the resource's {@link Path} 
121//       */
122//      @Deprecated
123//      public default Path getPath() {
124//              //return toPath(this.getURI());
125//              return Paths.get(getURI());
126//      }
127        
128//      public default URI getURI() {
129//              Class<?> clazz = this.getClass();
130//              String resourceName = getRelativePath();
131//              Objects.requireNonNull(resourceName);
132//              URI uri = null;
133//              if (this.isInsideJar()) {       // (classInsideJar(clazz))
134//                      String classPath = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation().getFile();
135//                      //String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', File.separatorChar);
136//                      String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', '/');
137//                      String compPath = "jar:file:" + classPath + "!/" + packagePath + "/" + resourceName;
138//                      try {
139//                              uri = new URI(compPath);
140//                      } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
141//                              throw new RuntimeException(e.toString());
142//                      }       
143//              }
144//              else {  // regular file path
145//                      try {
146//                              URL url = clazz.getResource(resourceName);
147//                              if (url != null) {
148//                                      uri = url.toURI();
149//                              }
150//                      } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
151//                              //do nothing, just return null
152//                      }
153//              }
154//              return uri;
155//      }
156        
157//      /**
158//       * Converts an {@link URI} to a {@link Path} for objects that are either
159//       * in the file system or inside a JAR file.
160//       * 
161//       * @param uri the specified {@link URI}
162//       * @return the associated {@link Path}
163//       */
164//      public static Path toPath(URI uri) {
165//              Path path = null;
166//              String scheme = uri.getScheme();
167//              switch (scheme) {
168//              case "jar":     {       // resource inside JAR file
169//                      FileSystem fs = null;
170//                      try { // check if this FileSystem already exists 
171//                              fs = FileSystems.getFileSystem(uri);
172//                      } catch (FileSystemNotFoundException e) {
173//                              // that's OK to happen, the file system is not created automatically
174//                      }
175//                      
176//                      if (fs == null) {       // must not create the file system twice
177//                              try {
178//                                      Map<String, Object> map = Collections.emptyMap();
179//                                      fs = FileSystems.newFileSystem(uri, map);       // FileSystems.newFileSystem(uri, Collections.<String, Object>emptyMap());
180//                              } catch (IOException e) {
181//                                      throw new RuntimeException(e.toString());
182//                              }
183//                      }
184//                      
185//                      String ssp = uri.getSchemeSpecificPart();
186//                      int startIdx = ssp.lastIndexOf('!');
187//                      String inJarPath = ssp.substring(startIdx + 1);  // in-Jar path (after the last '!')
188//                      path = fs.getPath(inJarPath);
189//                      break;
190//              }
191//              case "file": {  // resource in ordinary file system
192//                      path = Paths.get(uri);
193//                      break;
194//              }
195//              default:
196//                      throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot handle this URI type: " + scheme);
197//              }
198//              return path;
199//      }
200        
201        /**
202         * Returns true if the associated resource (class) is located inside a JAR file.
203         * 
204         * @return true if inside a JAR file
205         */
206        public default boolean isInsideJar() {
207                URL url = getClass().getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
208                String path = url.getPath();
209                File file = new File(path);
210                return file.isFile();
211        }
212
213//      static boolean classInsideJar(Class<?> clazz) {
214//      URL url = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
215//      String path = url.getPath();
216//      File file = new File(path);
217//      return file.isFile();
218//}
219        
220        /**
221         * Returns an {@link InputStream} for reading from this resource.
222         * See also {@link Class#getResourceAsStream(String)}.
223         * This method is not supposed to be overridden.
224         * 
225         * @return an {@link InputStream} for the associated resource
226         */
227        public default InputStream getStream() {
228                return getClass().getResourceAsStream(getRelativePath());
229        }
230
231}
